Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Building an International Component in the Aleutian-Alaska Primary Site through US Participation in Research Cruises of the German R/V Sonne
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction of one tectonic plate beneath another is a fundamental geologic process, which has many important potential human impacts, including earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. Subduction also plays a key role in shaping Earth's surface, and has been particularly important in the formation of continents. This project will allow a group of U.S. scientists from the University of South Carolina and the University of Wisconsin to participate in two research cruises of the German Research Vessel Sonne. The expedition of the Research Vessel Sonne will collect rock samples from the seafloor in the Alaska-Aleutian subduction system and adjacent Bering Sea region in June-July 2016. This area has many earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, but little is known about its early geologic history and evolution. Samples collected during these scientific cruises will be used to understand the evolution of the Aleutian Island arc and adjacent Bering Sea region over the past 50 million years. Graduate and undergraduate students will participate on the cruises and gain important sea-going experience. All post-cruise data will be made available to the public.

This project focuses on three scientific themes: (1) inception and early development of the Aleutian Island arc, (2) occurrence and composition of active volcanism in the western Aleutian arc, and (3) arc inputs - the age and composition of North Pacific Oceanic lithosphere. Dredging and subsequent geochemical and geochronologic studies will target submarine canyons and other exposed basement structures in the Aleutian forearc. Samples from these features will provide constraints on the timing and kinematics of Aleutian arc formation. Dredging will also target volcanic cones of the western Aleutian seafloor and fracture zones on the down-going north Pacific Plate. Samples from these features will be used to characterize inputs from subducted oceanic crust in the Aleutian arc and their relationship to regional patterns in along-strike geochemistry. These samples will also be used to provide improved understanding of the highly calc-alkaline western Aleutian seafloor volcanic rocks and their significance from the standpoint of geochemical source components for all Aleutian-Alaska volcanism, and for the source of arc volcanism globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The immediate goals of this project were to collect rock samples by dredging the seafloor in the Aleutian Islands and adjacent North Pacific region and produce preliminary geochemical datasets characterizing the samples. Typically, our projects have broader scientific goals, but this was a small, one-year study with funding only to collect samples and enough geochemical data to assess the suitability of the samples for future work. 

The seafloor sampling (dredging) was certainly a success. We conducted 150 dredges during the two legs of the R/V Sonne’s Expedition SO249 (June 4 – August 17, 2016). Approximately 80% of these dredges returned igneous rocks suitable for geochemical studies of the type that we plan to pursue. The total number of rock and sediment samples collected for the combined legs was 1459. 

Preliminary geochemical datasets were produced for samples falling in the three categories listed below. These categories are based on the types of seafloor structures where the samples were collected and on the expected ages of the samples. Sample locations are marked by green, pink, and blue dots on the map that accompanies this report.

(1) Volcanic & Plutonic Rocks from Aleutian Submarine Canyons: No radioisotopic dating of the samples has yet been done, but geologic relationships indicate that the youngest of these samples will be 5-10 million years old and the oldest will be 40-50 million years old. A key goal for subsequent studies will be to measure the ages of the samples and in particular to determine the time period in which Aleutian volcanism began. 

(2) Volcanic Rocks from Active Seafloor Volcanoes: West of Buldir Volcano (the westernmost emergent volcano in the Aleutian chain) the line of active, Aleutian volcanoes moves onto relatively thin crust of the Bering Sea. As a result, active volcanoes of the westernmost Aleutian arc lie below sea level. Our time spent collecting these samples was relatively short, but fortuitous timing allowed us to quickly incorporate geochemical results from these rocks into a research paper that was already in progress in May 2016 when our expedition began. Key results of the article, which was published in the journal Earth & Planetary Science Letters, are described below. 

(3) Volcanic Rocks from the Pacific Plate: South of the Aleutian trench and east of the Kamchatka trench we dredged seafloor of the Pacific Plate. No radioisotopic dating has yet been done, but we anticipate that Pacific Plate rocks east of the Emperor Seamounts and south of the Aleutian trench will be 40 to 60 million years old. Pacific Plate samples collected west of the Emperor Seamounts and southeast of the Kamchatka trench are likely to be 80 to 130 million years old.  

Results reported in the Earth & Planetary Science paper published during the funding period of this grant contribute to the long-term efforts of the lead investigator, which aim to improve our understanding of how subduction system plate boundaries work. Data reported in the study were collected at the University of South Carolina by routine analytical methods. A key conclusion of the paper is that the widely accepted (standard) models describing the formation of magmas in subduction zone may be in error in significant ways. The paper shows in particular, that the contribution of the subducting plate to the melting and magma-formation processes that leads to the creation of Aleutian Island volcanoes is greater than is generally realized. The implication is that physical models for subduction zones systematically under-estimate the temperature of the subducting oceanic crust as it passes beneath the line of active volcanism that parallels the plate boundary. Alternatively, it may be that models fail to appreciate the physical structure of the subducting plate, which may be broken or imbricated and dismembered in ways that cause it to be heated more efficiently than a whole and intact subducting plate, which is what the models assume.

This project also had an important student-training component. Three graduate students from the University of South Carolina participated in research cruises aboard a German research ship where they learned the basics of seafloor mapping and dredging as well as rock and sediment sample description and storage for archival purposes. While at sea, the South Carolina graduate students worked under the direction of German and Russian shift supervisors and in collaboration with German and Russian student cohorts. The South Carolina graduate students were also responsible for post-cruise geochemical sample preparation and analysis using various methods including major and trace element analysis by XRF, trace element analysis by QICPMS, and isotope ratio measurement by MCICPMS.  This work involved extensive laboratory technical and safety training at the University of South Carolina. Financial support of graduate students during the post-cruise phase of the study was in the form of university-provided teaching assistantships, which require the students to teach laboratory sections of various undergraduate geology classes.
